body: Looks good, +1 to merge

Note on the tests of the streaming extensions: I couldn't find a more specific class than `SingleOutputStreamOperator[_]`, thus assertion may not be very meaningful. However, I'd leave them in place to make sure further work on the extension won't break them at compile time.
That is a good idea @uce :-) I'll add a corresponding test for the `ExecutionConfig`.
I've added an additional test case for registered user code types in the `ExecutionConfig`. I will rebase this PR and if travis gives green light, then I'll merge it.
Thanks! Hope it will make it to 1.0.1. :smile:
Failing test case seems to be unrelated
Manually merged in 9aa207c073f878d711ca8107627c1f9b2ac17507
Looks good to merge...
Merging this...

Looks pretty good. I noticed three remaining things:
- Sometimes, the package name and the directory path is different (example: `OnCoGroupDataSetTest.scala` is not in an `impl` directory). While Scala allows that, we usually keep them in sync.
- The classes that implement the "withX" functions sometimes have context bounds that I think they should not require (see inline comment above). Would be great to remove them, because removing them later makes it API breaking.
- We need to decide how to label this for the future: stable, or evolving. I would suggest to use `@PublicEvolving` on all the involved classes for now.

The code looks good now.
- How about we move all the convenience timestamp extractors / watermark generators into a separate packe `.functions.timestamps`?

**Docs**
I am a bit unsure about the docs. They seem to get confusing now. What is a mechanism (periodic / punctuated), what is just a convenience implementation (Ascending, BoundedOutOfOrderness).

How about leaving the docs page on watermark generation as it is and add another sub-page that lists pre-defined watermark generators. We would list all the future watermark generators there:
- ascending timestamps
- bounded out-of-orderness
- historgam based

From my side, +1 for removing the `ProgramDescription` interface.

I think it is a mismatch with the `main()` method based approach, because it needs to instantiate the class, while the general entry point is static. That does not go well together in my opinion. People will write programs with no default constructor. Previously, with the `Program` interface, such a constructor was also mandatory, it did fit better there.

Thanks, I like the docs now! Sorry for nitpicking, but could you - Make the bullet list in the docs use the html tags (`
`)? It does not render properly in the docs otherwise. - Write references to for example `DataSet` as `DataStream`/`DataSet`? I think the DataStream API is used more by now, so would be nice to have it in there.

I think @smarthi has a point that the functionality is a nice fit for `DataSetUtils` and he has properly added it to the scala API and covered the tests.
It is true that it has some minor refactoring obfuscating the core PR, but besides that LGTM. If noone thinks otherwise I would merge this Tuesday morning with optionally excluding the refactor parts if it is considered that bothersome.
Unfortunately for the Mahout release I think the policy is as @fhueske suggests that we should reserve new features for the next, 1.1.0 release line.

@mbalassi : There is already request from @zentol and me to clean up the PR, so would love to get this merge excluding the refactor parts. Thanks.

I think we should merge this to master and 1.1.0, the question is whether this should go to 1.0.1 release, which @fhueske and @uce think should not.
OK, no problem, I've updated the PR.
Closing this PR without merging as its "way too specific", thanks for all the feedback.
@smarthi I think it's not too specific at all since its part of `DataSetUtils` and not `DataSet`. Let's merge the changes to master for `1.1`.

+1 for merging to master. 

But would love to isolate the changes to exclude refactoring changes if possible

I have done the changes only to support the String concat operation. The cast() and abs() grammar change looks more complex and I need to understand things better in parser to support it. Suggest we do it in a seperate JIRA?  Is that fine @tillrohrmann ?
Thanks for updating the PR @ramkrish86. Your proposed approach (creating a new PR for the parser changes) would be fine with me.
That is a good point with the instantiation of the instances. I will update the PR accordingly.
Removed the `ProgramDescription` interface and rebase the PR on the latest master.
Thank you @tillrohrmann . Let me if the changes in the updated PR is fine with you.

Hello! This PR simply updates the documentation to reflect recent changes to the code. 
Could somebody review this?
@nikste Could you rebase to the latest master?
Moving this to #1849 due to git eating my changes when rebasing under the new dir structure.

@mbalassi @tillrohrmann 

Closed the previous PR and opened this one for the evaluation framework, as I had some issues with rebasing.

Just noticed that we added the zookeeper.connect to the wrong file. This belongs to the consumer not the producer.
Will fix it.

Hello @StephanEwen 

I totally agree with the comments.

I rearranged the extractors and integrated your comments on the documentation.
I left the BoundedOutOfOrderness example where it was, as this is not pre-implemented extractor, but a code snippet illustrating how to correctly implement the provided interfaces.

Please review.
@mxm rebased to master and added documentation
@StephanEwen Thanks for the feedback, I've addressed the points you highlighted and took the time to add some missing Scaladoc to the `DataStream` extension.
You're right, sorry. I can fix this right now.
Its fine, I fixed it already and will push a hotfix.
Ok, thanks!
How about renaming `benv` to `batchEnv` and `senv` to `streamEnv`? Makes the two more distinct from each other and the names more self-explanatory.

Apparently https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-2880 has been fixed with Kafka 0.9.0.1. Still, we should make sure that the multiple (I'd say at least 10) test runs are passing without failure.

I'll look into this once its building.
Looks good to merge. @zentol Could you rebase this to the latest master?

Looks good to me. Will merge this finally!

Thanks for the hard work and the many iterations here...

I was following @StephanEwen 's suggestion above here:

> The Scala community seems to like brevity (senv vs. streamEnv).
@skyahead Will you be fixing the compile issue of this pull request?
I prefer `senv` and `benv` because it is shorter than `streamEnv` and `batchEnv`. In shell, shorter variables would be better even though there is a auto-complete support.
Will merge this if there are no further comments.

We still have the issue of the name. I don't like to have "lateness" in the name, as "lateness" so far refers to either events coming behind watermarks (nothing to do with watermark generator), or event time being late with respect to processing time.

In that sense, I still think `BoundedOutOfOrderness` would be a better name.

Other comment: Would be nice to retain a deprecated version of the `AscendingTimestampExtractor` in its original place (stub that extends to relocated copy) in order to not break user code.

This looks quite good. I made two inline comments. After addressing those, this should be good to merge.

Thanks for addressing this issue!
LGTM. Perhaps we could add a test case for this example?

Looks good, merging this...

Thanks for updating these docs!

Thanks for the fix, looks good!

Merging this...
This is an additional example that runs forever -- it was never designed for getting tested. Furthermore, there are already two test for split-stream functionality.
As you wish, I don't mind. I only felt it was hard to read and to keep apart.
IMHO we should have a way to check that examples are working properly. We don't have to address this in this PR though.
It's been a pleasure, thanks for the patience and for guiding me through the iterations. :smiley:

Hello @StephanEwen , 
I integrated your comments.
Please review and let me know if there is any other issue.

Very nice work. 

After an offline chat with @aljoscha , we concluded to slightly adjust the `Trigger` interface to make it simpler for people to develop triggers.

Other than that, this is good to merge...
Makes sense. Given that the CI tests run, I am okay with merging this...
Change example slightly (make it run finite and added a check for even/odd stream) and added IT-Case.

I did the changes, I introduced `canMerge()` and added a default `onMerge()` that throws a `RuntimeExeption` in `Trigger`. This way we don't break the API for already existing user triggers.

If there are no objections I will also merge the removal of the non-keyed window operator that this PR is based on.
Merging ...

The code looks good, but the tests are bound to be unstable. Making the assumption that sleeps actually sleep as long as they should is often violated (seems especially on Travis).

I think we need to find a better way to test this...

How about adjusting the test such that it works the following way:
- it polls the number of checkpoint calls (from the atomic integer), say every 100 ms
- it starts measuring time from when the count goes to `1`
- it validates that `(numCalls - 2) * pause` is always smaller than the elapsed time since starting the time measurement

Let's not merge this as is, it uses again a static de-duplicator, like the DataSet API used to (we recently eliminated that). These static utils to work around putting adding variable in the right place is an antipattern.

Why not have the registration de-duplicator in the ExecutionEnvironment? Since the ExecutionCondig is also one-per environment, and is always accessed through the environment, that seems like the way to go...
Just rebased. Waiting for Travis and then merging to `master` and `release-1.0`.
The documentation for `zipWithIndex` now references requiring two passes and notes `zipWithUniqueId` as an alternative.
@vasia do you know what software was used to create the graphs in the existing Gelly documentation?
Hi @greghogan, it's google drawings.

No problem @StephanEwen ! 
Thanks for merging this.
i decided against the ExecutionEnvironment because i do not want to add a method (to access the deduplicator) in a user-facing class, when a user would never use it.
Should we add this for `1.0.2` (or `1.0.1` if the RC gets cancelled)?
Perhaps there should be two flags, PARALLELISM_DEFAULT = -1 to reset the parallelism to the system default, and PARALLELISM_UNKNOWN = -2 which leaves the parallelism unchanged.

I think static variable is even more problematic.
Other possibility is to traverse the graph at the very end, and register at that point what is encountered.
Concerning the removal of the non-keyed window operator: Does that mean that the user functions now see the dummy key?
Can do, yes. But we shouldn't block, as you said.
I'm not sure if we can register the KeySelector types that way.

No, we introduced the `InternalWindowFunction` before 1.0.0 to decouple the user `WindowFunction` from the window operator implementation. There are now special `InternalWindowFunctions` that don't forward the key to the user function. The API for the user does not change, there an `AllWindowFunction` is used, as before. And that function does not get a key.

I'm seeing this failure on Travis: https://travis-ci.org/aljoscha/flink/jobs/120638971

Could be a bug introduced by the change. I'm investigating...
Would you mind triggering a few builds over night?
done :smile:

Do you prefer the look of hand-crafted graphs or should we consider something that will draw graphs in the browser like [JSNetworkX](http://jsnetworkx.org/index.html)? This is BSD licensed. They have yet to fully implement NetworkX but these graph generators map to generators in NetworkX.
Let's find a way then :-)
Sorry about commits a lot , I have some trouble in rebase & IDE space problem. This version might be ok.
@rmetzger Given that the Kafka bug is fixed, can we drop the re-try loop, or was that intended to also cover other cases (like brokers having inconsistent metadata) ?

For the test, two comments:
- Can you add it to another ITCase (saves bringing an extra mini cluster)
- Also, it will probably not run on windows. Writing to a temp file and deleting that should make this compatible.
The deduplicator set is only used to prevent infinite resursion for recursive types, correct? if so, can't we just pass an empty set into the method?
Done. I needed to restructure class hierarchy, because `StreamingMultipleProgramsTestBase` did not provided methods for tmp-file handling...
+1 for merging :-)
Yes, we can drop the retry loop.

I think the functionality is very desirable. In many cases, you really don't want Flink to write something to Zookeeper for some random GroupId. This floods ZooKeeper with garbage that helps no one.

I think that this is actually a kind of nice solution. The `auto.commit.enable` in Flink means not necessary periodically, but "on checkpoint or periodically".
Manually merged.
Rebased.
@twalthr is this still valid with the changes in the Table API or can it be closed?
@twalthr @fhueske @vasia Is this still valid with the recent changes in the Table API?
hi @dalegaard this must have slipped my mind. I'll review it tomorrow and merge if possible.
@ggevay The windowing system changed a while back. Is this still valid or can it be closed?
I think that this unfortunately can't be adapted to the new windowing system, so it can be closed.

The changes look good. One thing I would like to have changed is to rename `SimpleWriterBase` to `StreamWriterBase` or `StreamWriter` based to reflect the fact that it is used for Stream based writers.
@aljoscha okay, I'll fix that and rebase onto master. Naming things is one of the only two hard problems in computer science after all :)
reworked test to be more reliable.
